subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: * In mainland China (based on {{w|GB 18030}} encoding standard), Japanese {{w|kanji}} and Vietnamese [[Nôm]], the left component is {{l|mul|答}}. * In Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau (based on {{w|Big5}} encoding standard), the bottom component is {{l|mul|㓣}}, which is the orthodox form found in the {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}. Note that this form is identical with that of {{l|mul|箚}} (U+7B9A). * Due to {{w|Han unification}}, this character will appear differently depending on the font used.

subSections.title: Related characters
subSections.text:
* {{l|mul|[[札]]}} ''(Orthodox form of ''{{l|mul|剳}}, <font size=4, lang=zh-Hans>劄</font>'' in mainland China)''
* {{l|mul|[[剳]]}} ''({{w|Variant Chinese character|Variant form}} of {{l|mul|札}} in mainland China. Variant form of ''<font size=4, lang=zh-Hant>劄</font>'' in Taiwan)'' <!-- Refer https://www.moedict.tw/剳 -->
* {{l|mul|[[箚]]}} ''(Orthodox form based on {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}. Also a duplicate of the form used in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau for this character)''

subSections.title: Glyph origin
Usage notes
subSections.text: This glyph form is considered a {{w|Variant Chinese character|variant form}} of {{l|zh|札}} in mainland China but not in Taiwan. <!-- Refer character 3532, https://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/通用規范漢字表 -->

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: This glyph form is considered a {{w|Variant Chinese character|variant form}} of {{l|zh|⿱[[𥫗]][[㓣]]}} in Taiwan but not in mainland China.

subSections.title: References
subSections.text: * {{R:twedu|B03225-003}} <!-- Note: This reference belongs to Glyph 1, Etymology 2 -->

subSections.title: Definitions
subSections.text:
{{zh-hanzi}}

# {{lb|zh|mainland China|traditional Chinese medicine}} {{zh-used in|目劄|type of [[eye]] related [[illness]]}}. <!-- Refer character 7692, https://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/通用規范漢字表 -->

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text: Found in the authoritative {{w|Kangxi dictionary}} published during the {{w|Qing dynasty}} in 1716 AD.
